The Pick-Sloan Tribal Commission for Comprehensive Resolution is established with 7 members, including a Chairperson, experts in Indian law, Federal water projects, environmental justice, and an economist. The Pick-Sloan Tribal Commission for Comprehensive Resolution consists of 7 members, with expertise in Indian law, Federal water projects, environmental justice, economics, and cultural preservation. At least 3 members must be from federally recognized Indian tribes. The selection of commission members is done by the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs and the Chairperson and Ranking Member of the House Committee on Natural Resources. The Pick-Sloan Tribal Commission for Comprehensive Resolution consists of 7 members appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled promptly. Recommendations for members can be made by affected Indian tribes to the respective committee chairpersons. The Commission consists of 7 members appointed promptly, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The initial meeting must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings are called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission, exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act, consults with affected Indian tribes and conducts a study on the impacts of the Pick-Sloan Program and proposed measures to address them. The Commission will hold hearings to address the impacts on Indian tribes caused by the Pick-Sloan Program and compare them to other situations involving Federal hydroelectric projects and Indian land. The Commission will hold at least 3 public hearings to gather information from Federal agencies, Indian tribes, and other parties on resolving Pick-Sloan Program impacts. Records of each hearing will be compiled and included in the Commission's report as an electronic appendix. The Commission will develop a proposal to resolve impacts on Indian tribes from the Pick-Sloan Program, including a program for compensation and measures that have not been implemented yet. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 18 months of its first meeting, detailing measures to resolve impacts of the Pick-Sloan Program on affected Indian tribes, including administrative and legislative actions. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 18 months, detailing study findings, conclusions, and proposals for legislation and administrative actions to address impacts on affected Indian tribes from the Pick-Sloan Program. The deadline may be extended for up to 180 days with a request to the Senate and House committees. The Commission must submit a report to the President and Congress within 18 months, detailing study findings and proposals for legislation to address impacts on affected Indian tribes from the Pick-Sloan Program. The deadline can be extended for up to 180 days with a request to the Senate and House committees. Additionally, the Commission is required to maintain a website to describe its activities and provide access to information. The Commission is mandated to maintain a website to provide access to information, notice of hearings, and post reports. When the website is terminated, all content will be archived on digital media and included in the final report. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services as needed to carry out its duties under the Act. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, collect information from federal agencies, and utilize postal services as necessary. Additionally, the Commission can accept, use, and manage gifts or donations. Commission members are compensated at a rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule and are provided with travel expenses. The Commission has the authority to appoint staff, including an executive director, without following civil service laws. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the Commission, and their compensation is determined accordingly. The Commission can set the compensation for the executive director and staff without following civil service laws, with a maximum pay rate set at level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can detail federal government employees without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. It can also request human resources support from the Secretary of Defense on a reimbursable basis and has contract authority as provided in appropriation Acts. The Commission can enter into contracts and accept voluntary services to fulfill its duties. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at specified rates. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report. SEC. 5. FUNDING. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2010 and 2011, with funds remaining available until expended. Transfer of unobligated amounts by the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of the Army to the Commission for use in carrying out the Act. Transferred amounts remain available until the termination of the Commission. The Commission's termination date is based on the availability of funds to carry out the Act. SEC. 6. SAVINGS CLAUSE. This Act does not affect the water rights, treaty rights, reservation land status, or Congressional appropriations for affected Indian tribes.
